The effects of the ruling are on hold while a judicial review of a law referenced in the judge's opinion is pending.{{cite web|url=http://www.nacion.com/nacional/derechos-humanos/Comunidad-celebra-reconoce-primera-homosexual_0_1491250976.html |title=Comunidad gay celebra fallo que reconoce primera unión de hecho homosexual |publisher=Nacion.com |date=2015-06-02 |language=es}} | |- | {{flagicon|United States}} United States | June 2015 | In ''[[Obergefell v. Hodges]]'' the [[Supreme Court of the United States]] held that the [[Equal Protection Clause]] and the [[Due Process Clause]] of the [[Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution|Fourteenth Amendment]] require all states to license marriage between two people of the same sex and recognize those marriages performed in other jurisdictions.{{cite web |url=https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/14pdf/14-556_3204.pdf |publisher=Supreme Court of the United States |title=Syllabus: Obergefell et al. v. Hodges, Director, Ohio Department of Health, et al. -- Certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit }} |[[File:Yes check.svg|15px|Yes]] Yes |- | {{flagicon|Austria}} [[Recognition of same-sex unions in Austria|Austria]] | April 2016 | Austria's Constitutional court is expected to rule later this year over the constitutionality of the same-sex marriage ban.http://www.thelocal.at/20160323/families-fight-austrias-gay-marriage-ban |[[File:Yes check.svg|15px|Yes]] Yes |- | {{flagicon|Colombia}} [[Recognition of same-sex unions in Colombia|Colombia]] | April 2016 |The Constitutional Court unified the criteria after Congress did not meet its 2013 deadline and, in practice, only some judges were performing marriages. The 2016 ruling indicates that judges and notaries are obliged to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples.{{cite web|url=http://www.semana.com/nacion/articulo/homosexuales-ya-podran-darse-el-si-en-las-notarias/471332 |publisher=Semana |title= Homosexuales ya podrán darse el sí en notarias |date=2016-04-28 |language=es}} |[[File:Yes check.svg|15px|Yes]] Yes |- | {{flagicon|South Korea}} [[Recognition of same-sex unions in South Korea|South Korea]] | May 2016 | After [[Seodaemun District|Seodeamun-gu]] office refused to grant marriage licenses to a same-sex couple, they asked a court on May 21, 2014 to be married.{{cite web|url=http://www.yonhapnews.co.kr/society/2014/05/21/0701000000AKR20140521092200004.HTML |script-title=ko:김조광수 동성커플, 혼인신고 불수리처분에 불복 소송 |publisher=[[Yonhap]] |date=2014-05-21 |language=ko}} The first oral argument was held on July 6, 2015 in Seoul. On 25 May 2016, the district court ruled against the couple and declared that same-sex marriage can't be granted under the current laws. The couple quickly filed an appeal against the district court ruling. | |- | {{flagicon|Estonia}} [[Recognition of same-sex unions in Estonia|Estonia]] | August 2016 | A pair is challenging before the Administrative Court of Estonia on the right to enter into a civil union.{{Cite web|url=http://m.delfi.ee/eesti/article.php?id=75546971|title="Radari" video: Geiaktivist läheb kooseluseaduse tõttu riigiga kohtusse - Delfi Eesti|last=|first=|date=|website=m.delfi.ee|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-26}} | |- | {{flagicon|El Salvador}} [[Recognition of same-sex unions in El Salvador|El Salvador]] | August 2016 | The "Sala de lo Constitucional" is studying whether to admit or not a case against article 11 of the Family code which defines marriage as "the legal union between a man and a woman".{{Cite web|url=http://elmundo.sv/interponen-demanda-ante-sala-por-matrimonios-gay/|title=Interponen demanda ante Sala por matrimonios gay {{!}} Diario El Mundo|last=|first=|date=|website=elmundo.sv|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-26}} | |- | {{flagicon|China}} [[Recognition of same-sex unions in China|China]] | 2016 | The court in central Changsha dismissed the suit brought against the civil affairs bureau for refusing to issue a marriage license to a gay couple. One of the plaintiffs, 26-year-old Sun Wenlin, said he would appeal the decision.{{Cite web|url=http://m.dw.com/en/chinese-court-rejects-first-same-sex-marriage-case/a-19182830|title=Chinese court rejects first same-sex marriage case {{!}} News {{!}} DW.COM {{!}} 13.04.2016|last=|first=|date=|website=DW.COM|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-26}} | |- | {{flagicon|Bermuda}} [[LGBT rights in Bermuda|Bermuda]] | May 2017 | A gay Bermudian and his fiancé have been granted leave to argue in the Supreme Court that they should be allowed to wed on the island.{{Cite news|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/court/article/20160831/gay-couple-to-argue-for-marriage-in-court|title=Gay couple to argue for marriage in court {{!}} The Royal Gazette:Bermuda Court|newspaper=The Royal Gazette|access-date=2016-10-26}} On 5 May 2017 the ban on gay marriage within Bermuda was declared unconstitutional by a unanimous decision within the [[Supreme Court of Bermuda]]. The Bermuda Government responded with a [[domestic partnership]] law in February 2018.[http://www.royalgazette.com/news/article/20170506/landmark-same-sex-ruling] |[[File:Yes check.svg|15px|Yes]] Yes |- | {{flagicon|Georgia}} [[LGBT rights in Georgia (country)|Georgia]] | Litigation ongoing. Launched in 2016 | A man is challenging that while the civil code of Georgia is explicitly between a man and a woman; the Constitution does not reference sex/gender in its section on marriage.{{Cite news|url=http://www.eurasianet.org/node/77221|title=Gay Marriage Lawsuit Launched in Georgia|last=Lomsadze|first=Giorgi|date=8 February 2016|work=|newspaper=EurasiaNet|access-date=2016-10-26|via=}} | |- | {{flagicon|Albania}} [[LGBT rights in Albania|Albania]] | Litigation pending, launched in 2017 | An Albanian LGBT rights group, PRO LGBT, has filed a lawsuit requesting recognition of same-sex partnerships in the country's Family Code | |- | {{flagicon|Taiwan}} Taiwan | May 2017 | On 24 May 2017 the [[Judicial Yuan|Constitutional Court]] ruled that same-sex couples have a right to marry, and gave the legislature two years to adequately amend Taiwanese marriage laws. According to the court ruling, if amendments are not passed within two years, same-sex marriages will automatically become legal.[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-taiwan-lgbt-marriage-idUSKBN18K0UN] |[[File:Yes check.svg|15px|Yes]] Yes |- | {{flagicon|Panama}} Panama | Litigation pending | Two lawsuits have been filed regarding same-sex marriage in Panama and are before the Supreme Court of Justice.http://www.gaystarnews.com/article/panama-activists-start-new-push-marriage-equality/ The Episcopal Diocese of Panama in the Catholic Church has said they do not oppose the establishment of marriage equality within secular laws and oppose discrimination.http://nosgustas.com/Articulos/8852-la-iglesia-catolica-de-panama-a-favor-del-matrimonio-igualitario-civil.html | |- | {{flag|Philippines}} | Litigation pending | Arguments at the [[Supreme Court of the Philippines]] on same-sex marriage in response as part of the [[Falcis III vs. Civil Registrar-General]] case were heard June 19, 2018.https://news.abs-cbn.com/news/03/06/18/sc-sets-oral-arguments-on-same-sex-marriage | |- |{{flagicon|Hong Kong}} Hong Kong | Litigation Pending | In August 2018 The [[High Court (Hong Kong)|High Court]] heard a case seeking to recognise [[Civil union|civil partnerships]] in a preliminary hearing, and it is expected to be heard in the first half of 2019.{{cite web|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/community/article/2161287/woman-takes-unprecedented-step-advance-lgbt-cause-hong-kong |title=Woman takes unprecedented step to advance LGBT cause in Hong Kong and sues government over civil partnerships ban |publisher=South China Morning Post |date=24 August 2018}}[https://www.advocate.com/marriage-equality/2018/8/24/queer-hong-kong-woman-sues-civil-union-rights][https://www.gaystarnews.com/article/woman-sues-hong-kong-government-for-not-allowing-same-sex-civil-partnerships/] {{Infobox artefact | name = Taíno ritual seat | image = [[File:Taino ritual seat.jpg|260px]] | image_caption = | material = Wood, and gold | size = 44cm long, 22cm high, 13cm wide | writing = | created = AD 1200–1500 | discovered = [[Santo Domingo]], [[Caribbean]] | location = [[British Museum]], [[London]] | id = }}
The '''Taíno Ritual Seat''' is a [[Pre-Columbian era|Pre-Columbian]] wooden seat made in the form of a man on all fours. It was made by the [[Taíno people|Taino]] people and found in a cave near the city of [[Santo Domingo]] in the Dominican Republic.<ref name="bm"/> The seat was made before [[Christopher Columbus]] landed in the [[Caribbean]] and is an important remnant of the Taino culture and [[civilisation]] that existed before the arrival of Europeans.
==Description== The seat is made from the dense hardwood called [[Lignum vitae]]. In this case the Lignum vitae is from the ''[[Guaiacum officinale]]'' tree.<ref name="bm">[https://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/aoa/t/taino_ritual_seat.aspx Taino ritual seat] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151018032430/http://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/aoa/t/taino_ritual_seat.aspx |date=2015-10-18 }}, British Museum, accessed 6 October 2010</ref> This tree's flowers are the national flower of [[Jamaica]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jis.gov.jm/special_sections/Independence/symbols.html |title=National Symbols |work=Emancipation & Independence |publisher=Jamaica Information Service |accessdate=2010-10-07}}</ref> The small chair is made in the form of a man on all fours. The head is decorated with gold and the figure is carved with male genitals underneath.<ref>[https://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/collection_object_details.aspx?objectId=651811&partId=1&place=27462&plaA=27462-3-1&page=1 British Museum Collection]</ref>
==Importance== Duhos are carved seats found in the houses of Taino caciques or [[Paramount chief|chiefs]] throughout the [[Caribbean]] region. Duhos “figured prominently in the maintenance of Taino political and ideological systems . . . [and were] . . . literally seats of power, prestige, and ritual.” Duhos made of wood and stone have both been found, though those made of wood tend not to last as well as the stone chairs and are, therefore, much rarer.<ref>Conrad, Geoffrey W., John W. Foster, and Charles D. Beeker, “Organic artifacts from the Manantial de la Aleta, Dominican Republic: preliminary observations and interpretations”, ''Journal of Caribbean Archaeology''. 2:6, 2001.</ref> This seat is one of two Taíno seats called ''Duho'' in the British Museum that were originally found on the island of [[Hispaniola]]. The other is also modelled anthropomorphically on a man, but in that case the resemblance to a man on his stomach is more proportional.<ref name="timeline">{{cite web|title=The Taíno of the West Indies|url=http://www.worldtimelines.org.uk/world/americas/central_meso/AD1000-1521/taino|work=World Tim Line|publisher=British Museum|accessdate=7 October 2010}}{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}</ref><ref>[https://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/collection_object_details.aspx?objectId=664915&partId=1&place=11287&plaA=11287-3-1&page=1 British Museum Collection]</ref> There is another wooden duho in the collections of the [[British Museum]] that was found on the island of [[Eleuthera]] in the [[Bahamas]].<ref>[https://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/collection_object_details.aspx?objectId=659469&partId=1&place=9650&plaA=9650-3-2&page=1 British Museum Collection]</ref>
==Purpose== Some of the first people that Christopher Columbus met in the American continent were the [[Taino]] people. Their 7,000-year-old civilisation did not benefit from pre-colonial contact as many were later enslaved or died of disease. It was noted by early explorers that some of their time the Taino people were using [[hallucinogenic]] drugs. The drug and the [[Smoking pipe|pipes]] that were used are called [[cohoba]]. It is likely that one of these chiefs used this seat to smoke these drugs. The British Museum's seat has a bowl above the figures head, which may have been used to hold [[cohoba]] during rituals involving the [[Zemi]] gods.<ref name=heil>[http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/ho/08/canc/ho_1979.206.380.htm "Deity Figure (Zemi) Dominican Republic; Taino (1979.206.380)"] In Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History. New York: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, 2000 October 2006; retrieved 22 September 2009</ref>
==History of the World== This chair from the British Museum was chosen to be one of the [[A History of the World in 100 Objects|History of the World in 100 Objects]] which was a series of radio programmes that started in 2010 and that were created in a partnership between the [[BBC]] and the British Museum.<ref name="ahotw">{{cite web|title=Taíno Ritual Seat|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/ahistoryoftheworld/objects/nknww6EoQO-nKTncBvhNbw Taíno Ritual Seat|publisher=BBC|accessdate=11 October 2010}}</ref>

{{Other uses|Tiger lily (disambiguation){{!}}Tiger lily}} {{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = The Tiger Lillies | image = Tiger_Lillies_TFF_01.JPG | caption = The Tiger Lillies at [[TFF Rudolstadt]] 2013 | background = group_or_band | origin = London | genre = [[Dark cabaret]] | years_active = 1989–present | label = Misery Guts Music | website ={{url|tigerlillies.com/}} | current_members = * Martyn Jacques * Adrian Stout * Jonas Golland | past_members = * Phil Butcher * Adrian Huge * Mike Pickering }}
[[Image:Tigerlillies2.jpg|thumb|right|The band after a concert]]
'''The Tiger Lillies''' are a cult British musical trio formed in 1989 by singer-songwriter [[Martyn Jacques]]. Described as the forefathers of Brechtian Punk Cabaret,<ref>{{cite web|last=Meads|first=Glenn|title=Tiger Lillies play Queer Contact Date: 21 December 2011|url=http://www.whatsonstage.com/blackpool-theatre/news/12-2011/tiger-lillies-play-queer-contact_5887.html|work=What's on Stage|accessdate=11 March 2013}}</ref> the Tiger Lillies are well known for their unique sound and style which merges "the macabre magic of pre-war Berlin with the savage edge of punk".<ref>{{cite web|last=Mann|first=Tom|title=The Tiger Lillies – 20 years of deviant theatrics|url=http://www.fasterlouder.com.au/news/local/19268/The-Tiger-Lillies--20-years-of-deviant-theatrics|work=Faster Louder|accessdate=5 July 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140307021532/http://www.fasterlouder.com.au/news/local/19268/The-Tiger-Lillies--20-years-of-deviant-theatrics|archive-date=7 March 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==History== ===Formation and recent activity=== The band's name is rumoured to have been inspired by a murdered Soho prostitute called Lillie who used to dress up in animal print.<ref>{{cite news|last=McCall|first=Chris|title=Music Beyond The Edge: The Tiger Lillies|url=http://www.festmag.co.uk/archive/2010/99729-music_beyond_edge_tiger_lillies|accessdate=5 July 2015|newspaper=Fest|date=15 July 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160407034230/https://www.festmag.co.uk/archive/2010/99729-music_beyond_edge_tiger_lillies|archive-date=7 April 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="auto">{{cite news|last=Goldsmith|first=Kenneth|title=Criminal Castrati: The Tiger Lillies|url=http://wfmu.org/~kennyg/popular/articles/tigerlillies.html|accessdate=5 July 2015|newspaper=New York Press|date=13 May 1998}}</ref> Jacques, however, has stated that he named the band after a painting he had on his wall.<ref>{{cite web|title=Interview: The Tiger Lillies|url=https://www.tigerlillies.com/news/deviant-nationcom-interview|work=Deviant Nation|accessdate=5 July 2015}}</ref> The band formed in 1989 when Martyn Jacques placed an ad on [[Loot (magazine)|Loot]] looking for a drummer and a bass player for a new band. Adrian Huge and Phil Butcher (the band's first bassist who was succeeded by Adrian Stout in 1995)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tigerlillies.com/655884/band/bios|title=Bios|publisher=The Tiger Lillies|website = www.tigerlillies.com|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101201063509/http://tigerlillies.com/655884/band/bios|archivedate=December 1, 2010}}</ref> were the only musicians that got in touch with him and therefore became the original Tiger Lillies' drummer and bassist respectively.
In Spring 2012 Adrian Huge decided to take a leave of absence and was replaced by drummer Mike Pickering who toured with the Tiger Lillies from 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tigerlillies.com/450596/news/mister-huge.|title=Mister Huge.|date=April 3, 2012|website = www.tigerlillies.com|publisher=The Tiger Lillies|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425102722/http://www.tigerlillies.com/450596/news/mister-huge.|archivedate=April 25, 2012}}</ref> In early 2015 Pickering was in turn replaced by band's current drummer, Jonas Golland.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Jonas Golland {{!}} Band {{!}} The Tiger Lillies|url = https://www.tigerlillies.com/band/jonas-golland|website = www.tigerlillies.com|access-date = 2016-01-13}}</ref>
<gallery> File:Adrian Stout 01.JPG|Adrian Stout File:Martyn Jacques 02.JPG|Martyn Jacques File:Jonas Golland performing with Tiger Lillies at Yotaspace, Moscow, Russia, May 8th, 2017.jpg|Jonas Golland </gallery>
==Musical style== ''[[The Independent]]'' has described The Tiger Lillies as "a provocative and avant-garde three-piece band that combines cabaret, vaudeville, music-hall and street theatre",<ref>{{cite news|last=Cripps|first=Charlotte|title=Dark Tales of the Unexpected|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/theatre-dance/features/dark-tales-of-the-unexpected-77750.html|accessdate=5 July 2015|newspaper=The Independent|date=11 November 2003}}</ref> while Tim Arthur of [[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out]] has given a more imaginative description: "Imagine Kurt Weill conjuring up images of prewar Berlin while a falsetto vocalist screams, squeaks and squawks his way through every number like some rambling madman, and you've got the picture".<ref>{{cite news|last=Arthur|first=Tim|title=Time Out Review|url=https://www.tigerlillies.com/music/the-brothel-to-the-cemetary#roll-up|accessdate=5 July 2015|newspaper=Time Out London|date=9 November 1996|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150706121242/https://www.tigerlillies.com/music/the-brothel-to-the-cemetary#roll-up|archivedate=6 July 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Notorious for singing controversial songs involving bestiality, prostitution, blasphemy and all other vice imaginable, The Tiger Lillies are undoubtedly not for the easily offended.<ref>{{cite web|last=D.|first=Keith|title=FRINGE REVIEW – The Tiger Lillies Live in Concert (Pleasance)|url=http://www.edinburghspotlight.com/2010/08/review-the-tiger-lillies-live-in-concert-pleasance/|work=Edinburgh Spotlight|accessdate=5 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Cobley|first=Mike|title=The Tiger Lillies: Stories Full Of Eccentricity, Blasphemy & Weirdness!|url=http://magazine.brighton.co.uk/?SEC_ID=1&CAT_ID=21&ART_ID=2406|accessdate=5 July 2015|newspaper=Brighton Magazine|date= 4 October 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Music review: The Tiger Lillies|url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/music-review-the-tiger-lillies-1-766400|accessdate=5 July 2015|newspaper=The Scotsman|date=23 August 2009}}</ref> Their musical style is mainly influenced by [[Bertolt Brecht]] and [[Kurt Weill]]'s masterpiece [[The Threepenny Opera]] and pre-war Berlin cabaret but other influences such as gypsy and circus music, French chanson and British music hall tunes are also evident.<ref>{{cite web|last=Fractal|first=Suicide|title=Interviews: Martyn Jacques of The Tiger Lillies|url=http://suicidegirls.com/interviews/Martyn+Jacques+of+The+Tiger+Lillies/|work=Suicide Girls|accessdate=5 July 2015}}</ref><ref name="auto"/>
==Awards and nominations== * In 2002 their cult hit musical ''Shockheaded Peter'' was nominated for five [[Laurence Olivier Award|Olivier Awards]]. The show won the Olivier for Best Entertainment and [[Martyn Jacques]] won the Olivier for Best Supporting Performance in a Musical or Entertainment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.olivierawards.com/winners/view/item98540/olivier-winners-2002/|title=Olivier Winners 2002|website=Olivier Awards}}</ref> * In 2003 their album ''The Gorey End'' (in collaboration with the [[Kronos Quartet]] and writer, illustrator [[Edward Gorey]]) was nominated for Dominique de Rivaz's ''Luftbusiness'' (2008) a [[Grammy Award]] for Best Classical Crossover Album.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tigerlillies.com/471401/news/the-gorey-end-has-been-nominated-for-a-grammy|title=The Gorey End has been nominated for a Grammy|date=December 5, 2003|publisher=The Tiger Lillies|website = www.tigerlillies.com|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101201112026/http://tigerlillies.com/471401/news/the-gorey-end-has-been-nominated-for-a-grammy|archivedate=December 1, 2010}}</ref> * In 2012 their show ''The Tiger Lillies Perform Hamlet'', produced by Copenhagen's Republique Theatre and directed by acclaimed Danish director Martin Tulinius, was nominated for a [[Reumert prize|Reumert Award]] in the category Music Theatre/Show of the Year 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.cision.com/danish-agency-for-culture/r/on-tour--hamlet-as-musical-theatre-by-olivier-award-winners-the-tiger-lillies-and-new-danish-theatre,c9261314|title=ON TOUR: HAMLET as musical theatre by Olivier Award winners THE TIGER LILLIES and new Danish theatre Republique|date= May 18, 2012|website=news.cision.com|publisher=Danish Agency for Culture}} </ref>

page.title: The War on Poverty: 50 Years Later

revision.text:
"'''The War on Poverty: 50 Years Later'''" is a report by the [[United States House Committee on the Budget|Budget Committee]] of the [[United States House of Representatives]] published on March 3, 2014. It was published in recognition of the 50th anniversary of [[Lyndon B. Johnson]]'s 1964 [[State of the Union address]], in which he declared "an unconditional war on poverty in America".<ref name="WOPReportDocument">{{cite web|url=http://budget.house.gov/waronpoverty/|title=The War on Poverty: 50 Years Later|publisher=Budget Committee of the House of Representatives|accessdate=March 6, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The American Presidency Project|url=http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/index.php?pid=26787|publisher=University of South Carolina Beaufort|accessdate=March 6, 2014}}</ref>
== Report == The reports advances the argument that federal antipoverty programs suffer from defects that “penalize families for getting ahead” and that “the complex web of federal programs and sudden drop-off in benefits create extraordinarily high effective marginal tax rates,” both of which “reduce the incentive to work”.<ref>{{cite web|title=Paul Ryan Gets Serious About Poverty|url=http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2014-03-06/paul-ryan-gets-serious-about-poverty|publisher=Bloomberg BusinessWeek|accessdate=9 March 2014|date=6 March 2014}}</ref>
At the core of the report are recommendations to enact cuts to welfare, child care, college Pell grants and several other federal assistance programs.<ref name="WOP_report">{{cite web|last=Mascaro|first=Lisa|title=Rep. Paul Ryan calls for cuts in anti-poverty programs|url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-ryan-poverty-20140304,0,24042.story#ixzz2v8iTKEln|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=March 6, 2014|date=March 3, 2014}}</ref> In an appendix titled "Measures of Poverty", when the poverty rate is measured by including non-cash assistance from food stamps, housing aid and other federal programs, the report states that these measurements "[have] implications for both conservatives and liberals. For conservatives, this suggests that federal programs have actually decreased poverty. For liberals, it lessens the supposed need to expand existing programs or to create new ones."<ref name="WOPReportDocument"/><ref name="WOP_report"/>
== Reception == {{expand section|date=March 2014}} Several economists and social scientists, Amy Finkelstein, Jane Waldfogel, Chris Wimer, [[Jeffrey Brown (professor)|Jeffrey Brown]] and Barbara Wolfe, whose work had been referenced in the report said that [[Paul Ryan]], the committee's chairman, either misunderstood or misrepresented their research. One of the issues raised was that the report cites data from 1969 onward, and according to Waldfogel this ignores a full 36 percent of the decline in poverty using the Supplemental Poverty Measurement since 1967. <ref name="misrepresented">{{cite web |url=http://www.thefiscaltimes.com/Articles/2014/03/04/Economists-Say-Paul-Ryan-Misrepresented-Their-Research |title=Economists Say Paul Ryan Misrepresented Their Research |last1=Garver |first1=Rob |date=March 4, 2014 |work=The Fiscal Times |accessdate=March 5, 2014}}</ref> Brown stated after the article's publication that Ryan quoted his research accurately, and that the ''Fiscal Times'' misrepresented his comments.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.economics21.org/commentary/war-paul-ryan |title=The War on Paul Ryan |publisher=Manhattan Institute |date=March 5, 2014}}</ref> The ''Financial Times '' later updated the article based on Brown's comment.<ref name="misrepresented"/> All of the statistical errors were later corrected, and Waldfogel's criticism was fixed.<ref name="WOPReportDocument"/>
== Report contents == {{expand section|date=March 2014}} * Introduction * Chapter 1: Cash Aid * Chapter 2: Education and Job Training * Chapter 3: Energy * Chapter 4: Food Aid * Chapter 5: Health Care * Chapter 6: Housing * Chapter 7: Social Services * Chapter 8: Veterans * Appendix I: Measures of Poverty * Appendix II: Data
== See also == * [[War on Poverty]]
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}

page.title: Trans-Universal Zombie Church of the Blissful Ringing

revision.text:
[[File:Zombi.png|thumb|Religious symbol of the church]] The '''Trans-Universal Zombie Church of the Blissful Ringing''' ({{lang-sl|Čezvesoljska Zombi Cerkev blaženega zvonjenja}}) is a contemporary religion in [[Slovenia]], founded in March 2013 and registered in the national registry of religious communities in 2014.<ref name="rtvslo1">{{cite web|url=http://www.rtvslo.si/mmc-priporoca/zombi-cerkev-zalitev-je-da-nam-recejo-da-nismo-vera/335694 |title=Zombi cerkev: Žalitev je, da nam rečejo, da nismo vera :: Prvi interaktivni multimedijski portal, MMC RTV Slovenija |publisher=Rtvslo.si |date=2014-04-29 |accessdate=2016-11-20}}</ref> As of late 2014, the church had over 10,000 members, making it the fifth largest religion in Slovenia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.24ur.com/ekskluziv/zanimivosti/zombi-cerkev-dobila-svojo-biblijo.html |title=Zombi cerkev dobila svojo biblijo |publisher=24ur.com |date=2014-10-29 |accessdate=2016-11-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rt.com/news/217235-slovenia-zombie-church-corruption/ |title='In the name of the Holy Pot': Zombie Church preaches against corruption in Slovenia — RT News |publisher=Rt.com |date=2014-12-24 |accessdate=2016-11-20}}</ref>
==Origins== The religion's origins are tied to the [[2012–13 Slovenian protests]] where thousands of people protested against members of the Slovenian political elite, including the mayor of [[Maribor]] [[Franc Kangler]], the Prime Minister of Slovenia [[Janez Janša]], the opposition leader and mayor of [[Ljubljana]] [[Zoran Jankovič]], and corruption in politics in general.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.delo.si/novice/ljubljana/v-zivo-protesti-v-ljubljani.html |title=(V živo): Protesti v Ljubljani |publisher=Delo.si |date= |accessdate=2016-11-20 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161121171319/http://www.delo.si/novice/ljubljana/v-zivo-protesti-v-ljubljani.html |archive-date=2016-11-21 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=I. H. |url=http://www.zurnal24.si/d-clanek-176333 |title=Zakaj Jankovič ne mobilizira kot Kangler – zurnal24 |publisher=Zurnal24.si |date= |accessdate=2016-11-20}}</ref> The church originally formed as The Church of the Blissful Ringing and later added "Zombie" and "Trans-Universal" to the name,<ref name="delo">{{cite web|url=http://www.delo.si/zgodbe/nedeljskobranje/cisto-prava-cerkev-zombi-cerkev.html |title=Čisto prava Cerkev. Zombi Cerkev |publisher=Delo.si |date=2014-05-11 |accessdate=2016-11-20}}</ref> the former because of the ruling [[Slovenian Democratic Party]] labelling the protesters as [[zombie]]s during the people's uprising.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.24ur.com/novice/slovenija/janseva-stranka-ne-vidi-protestnikov-temvec-zombije.html |title=SDS na Twitterju: Vstaja zombijev, ne pa vstaja naroda |publisher=24ur.com |date=2012-12-21 |accessdate=2016-11-20}}</ref> The official name was chosen using a [[Facebook]] poll and the church uses this social network for various activities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sobotainfo.com/novica/globalno/zombi-cerkev-zalitev-je-ce-nam-recejo-parodija-mi-smo-zelo-resna-cerkev/97387 |title=Zombi cerkev: Žalitev je, če nam rečejo parodija. Mi smo zelo resna cerkev |language=sl|publisher=Sobotainfo.com |date=2014-12-05 |accessdate=2016-11-20}}</ref> In 2014, the church was registered in the national registry of religious communities, which, as of 2016, contains 48 churches and other religious communities.<ref name="mk">{{cite web|url=http://www.mk.gov.si/si/delovna_podrocja/urad_za_verske_skupnosti/register_cerkva_in_drugih_verskih_skupnosti/|publisher=mk.gov.si|title=Register cerkva in drugih verskih skupnosti - Ministrstvo za kulturo|accessdate=2016-11-20}}</ref> The church also started gaining members in the neighbouring [[Croatia]].<ref name="rtvslo1"/> With more than 10,000 members, the church is the fifth largest religion in Slovenia, after the [[Roman Catholic Church]], [[Islam]], [[Serbian Orthodox Church]], and the [[Lutheran Church]].<ref name="delo"/>
==Beliefs and activities== [[File:Sveta maša pred hramom korupcije 5.JPG|thumb|Holy mass of the church in front of the National Assembly building]] According to the members of the church, the theology and the rituals are not strictly defined. The members should believe in the "Bell" and that the Universe begun with a "Big Bong", which took place before the [[Big Bang]]. Among other things, the church requires members to have sex once per week and forbids planting of [[genetically modified crops]] and sexual assaults. Initially, the holy drinks of the church were [[beer]], [[piña colada]], and water, but this was later extended to include all drinks that members enjoy.<ref name="delo"/> The church states that it allows its members to adhere to some other religion as well but requires all members to be at least 15 years old. The church plans to officiate weddings, including same-sex marriages.<ref name="delo"/>
Every Wednesday, the members of the church gather around the "Temple of Corruption" (the [[National Assembly Building of Slovenia]]) for holy mass. During the mass, they use pots, pans, and bells to produce clanking sounds.<ref name="yahoo1">{{cite web|author=Bojan Kavcic |url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/zombie-church-helps-slovenia-crucify-corrupt-leaders-042155991.html?ref=gs |title='Zombie church' helps Slovenia crucify corrupt leaders |publisher=Yahoo.com |date=2014-12-23 |accessdate=2016-11-20}}</ref> In addition, the members are active in various charity activities, such as helping people without health insurance, homeless, single mothers, and in 2016 also [[Syrian refugees]].<ref name="delo"/><ref>{{cite web|author=Polona Krušec |url=http://svet24.si/clanek/zanimivosti/54e5bd748fbe2/slovenska-zombi-cerkev-pomaga |title=Slovenska Zombi cerkev pomaga |publisher=Svet24.si |date= |accessdate=2016-11-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author=Posted by Teja R |url=https://glassroomglobe.com/2015/09/26/zombies-saving-refugees/ |title=Zombies saving refugees – The Glassroom Globe |publisher=Glassroomglobe.com |date=2015-09-26 |accessdate=2016-11-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161121045726/https://glassroomglobe.com/2015/09/26/zombies-saving-refugees/ |archivedate=2016-11-21 |df= }}</ref>
==Public perception== The Trans-Universal Zombie Church of the Blissful Ringing received a mixed reception upon formation. It has been labelled as a [[parody religion]] by a sociologist dr. Marjan Smrke,<ref name="delo"/> who compared it to the [[Church of the Flying Spaghetti Monster]] and [[Jediism]]. He considered the role of the church positive since it acts a reflection of the problems facing the Roman Catholic Church in Slovenia. The registration of the church drew criticism from a Catholic association Zavod za družino in kulturo življenja KUL, as being an insult to the Catholic community in Slovenia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.delo.si/novice/slovenija/upasana-in-zombi-cerkev-sta-uzalili-del-katolicanov.html |title=Upasana in Zombi cerkev sta užalili del katoličanov |publisher=Delo.si |date=2014-04-16 |accessdate=2016-11-20}}</ref> The Archbishop of Ljubljana, [[Stanislav Zore]], stated that the registration of religious communities falls within the responsibility of the government which has to outline clear criteria to see what constitutes a religious community.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://reporter.si/clanek/slovenija/nadskof-zore-ne-zelim-nic-vec-in-nic-manj-pravic-kot-jih-imajo-kristjani-drugje-po-evropi-436575 |title=Nadškof Zore: Ne želim nič več in nič manj pravic, kot jih imajo kristjani drugje po Evropi - Revija Reporter |publisher=Reporter.si |date= |accessdate=2016-11-20}}</ref> Critics mentioned that a motivation for the formation of the church included avoiding the upcoming real estate tax, from which certain religious objects are exempt.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rtvslo.si/slovenija/nove-verske-skupnosti-so-upasana-cezvesoljska-zombi-cerkev-kairos/353243 |title=Nove verske skupnosti so Upasana, Čezvesoljska zombi cerkev, Kairos... :: Prvi interaktivni multimedijski portal, MMC RTV Slovenija |publisher=Rtvslo.si |date= |accessdate=2016-11-20}}</ref> On the other hand, Ales Crnic, a cultural studies professor at Ljubljana University, stated that "[The church] is a criticism of the modern state that has been failing to fulfil its social commitments."<ref name="yahoo1"/>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{Commons category}} *[http://cezvesoljskacerkev.weebly.com/ Official website]

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2017}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=June 2014}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Virginia Braun | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = <!--(as myimage.jpg, no 'File:')--> | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = <!-- {{Birth date|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | birth_place = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} --> | other_names = | residence = | citizenship = | nationality = New Zealand | fields = [[thematic analysis]] and [[gender studies]] | workplaces = [[University of Auckland]] | patrons = | alma_mater = [[Loughborough University]] | thesis_title = The vagina: an analysis | thesis_url = http://lb-primo.hosted.exlibrisgroup.com/LB_VU1:local:LOUGH_DSP2134/7539 | thesis_year = 2000 | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = [[Sue Wilkinson (professor)|Sue Wilkinson]] and [[Celia Kitzinger]] | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | influences = | influenced = | awards = | signature = <!--(filename only)--> | signature_alt = | website = <!-- {{URL|www.example.com}} --> | footnotes = | spouse = | children = }} '''Virginia '''"'''Ginny'''"''' Braun''' is a New Zealand psychology academic specialising in [[thematic analysis]] and [[gender studies]].
==Academic career==
After undergraduate studies at the [[University of Auckland]], Braun received a Commonwealth Scholarship to [[Loughborough University]] with [[Celia Kitzinger and Sue Wilkinson]] as her advisors for her 2000 thesis ''The vagina: an analysis''.
Braun returned to Auckland in 2001,rising to full Professor in 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.psych.auckland.ac.nz/en/about/news-and-events/events/events-2017/06/inaugural-lecture-by-professor-virginia-braun.html |title=Inaugural lecture by Professor Virginia Braun: Telling tales of gendered bodies – The University of Auckland |publisher=Psych.auckland.ac.nz |date=15 June 2017 |accessdate=27 June 2017}}</ref>
Her 2006 paper ''Using thematic analysis in psychology'' with [[Victoria Clarke|Victoria Clarke (psychologist)]] in [[Qualitative research in psychology]] has more than twenty thousand references according to [[Google Scholar]].
Braun was editor of [[Feminism & Psychology]] between 2008 and 2013. She received a Distinguished Leadership Award from the American Psychological Association’s Committee on Women in Psychology in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sexualpoliticsnow.org.nz/about/people/ |title=People |publisher=Sexual Politics Now |date=28 January 2015 |accessdate=27 June 2017}}</ref>
In 2015/2016 Braun went public with her experiences seeking a [[tubal ligation]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nowtolove.co.nz/health/body/the-kiwi-woman-who-campaigned-to-be-sterilised-13730 |title=The Kiwi woman who campaigned to be sterilised |publisher=Now To Love |date=17 May 2016 |accessdate=27 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/life-style/parenting/pregnancy/74488372/motherhood-not-for-every-woman-professor-says |title=Motherhood not for every woman, professor says |publisher=Stuff.co.nz |date=27 November 2015 |accessdate=27 June 2017}}</ref>
== Selected works == * Virginia Braun, Victoria Clarke and Debra Gray, ''Collecting qualitative data. A practical guide to textual, media and virtual techniques.'' [[Cambridge University Press]]. 2017. {{ISBN|9781107054974}} * Virginia Braun, [[Nicola Gavey]], and Kathryn McPhillips. "The fair deal'? Unpacking accounts of reciprocity in heterosex." [[Sexualities (journal)|Sexualities]] 6, no. 2 (2003): 237-261.

{{Infobox person | image = Vishakha63s.jpg | caption = | birth_name = Vishakha Nirubhai Desai | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1949|05|1|df=y}} | birth_place = Ahmedabad, Gujarat, India | death_date = | death_place = | other_names = | residence = {{nowrap|New York City, New York, U.S.}} | alma_mater = | nationality = American | occupation = | years_active = | employer = | title = Senior Advisor for Global Affairs to President Lee C. Bollinger [[Columbia University]] | boards = | religion = | spouse = [[Robert Oxnam|Dr. Robert B. Oxnam]] | children = }}
'''Dr. Vishakha N. Desai''' is an Asia scholar with a focus on art, culture, policy, and women’s rights. She currently serves as Senior Advisor for Global Affairs to the President of [[Columbia University]], Senior Research Scholar in Global Studies at its [[School of International and Public Affairs]] and Vice-Chair of the [http://cgt.columbia.edu/ Committee on Global Thought] at Columbia University. She is President Emerita of the [[Asia Society]] (2004 – 2012).<ref>Columbia News Staff, “Asia Society’s Vishakha Desai to Join Columbia as Special Advisor for Global Affairs and Faculty Member,” On Campus Columbia University, 4 October 2012, http://news.columbia.edu/oncampus/2907.</ref> In recognition of her leadership in the museum field, President Barack Obama appointed her to serve on the National Commission on Museums and Libraries in 2012.<ref>"Vishakha N. Desai," Bertelsmann Foundation, http://www.bfna.org/person/vishakha-n-desai.</ref> Dr. Desai has been recognized as one of the "[http://www.crainsnewyork.com/gallery/20070916/FEATURES/309169999/35 Most Powerful Women in New York]" by Crains Magazine, and for her Distinguished Service to the Visual Arts by ArtTable.<ref>"Miriam Kreinin Souccar, Most Powerful Women in New York 2007: Vishakha Desai," Crain's New York Business, http://www.crainsnewyork.com/gallery/20070916/FEATURES/309169999/35.</ref> She is a recipient of five honorary degrees from Centre College, Pace University, the College of Staten Island, Susquehanna University, and Williams College.<ref>Columbia News Staff, “Asia Society’s Vishakha Desai to Join Columbia as Special Advisor for Global Affairs and Faculty Member,” On Campus Columbia University, 4 October 2012, http://news.columbia.edu/oncampus/2907; "Vishakha N. Desai," Pace University Honorary Degree Citations, http://www.pace.edu/current-students/commencement-2009/general-information/honorary-degree-recipients/vishakha-n-desai; "Williams College Announces its 2014 Honorary Degree Recipients," Williams College, http://communications.williams.edu/news-releases/3_19_2014_honorarydegree/.</ref>
== Life and career ==
'''Dr. Vishakha N. Desai''' is Senior Advisor for Global Affairs to the President of [[Columbia University]] and Senior Research Scholar in Global Studies at the [[School of International and Public Affairs]].<ref>Columbia News Staff, “Asia Society’s Vishakha Desai to Join Columbia as Special Advisor for Global Affairs and Faculty Member,” On Campus Columbia University, 4 October 2012, http://news.columbia.edu/oncampus/2907.</ref>
Dr. Desai served as President and CEO of the [[Asia Society]], a global organization dedicated to strengthening partnerships among peoples of Asia and the U.S. from 2004 through 2012. As President, she set the direction for the Society’s diverse sets of programs ranging from policy initiatives and national educational programs to ground breaking exhibitions and performing arts programs throughout its network of eleven offices in the U.S. and Asia. Under her leadership the society expanded the scope and scale of its activities with the opening of new offices in India and Korea, a new center of U.S.–China Relations, various leadership initiatives, and inauguration of two new architecturally distinguished facilities in Hong Kong and Houston.<ref>"Vishakha N. Desai," Pace University Honorary Degree Citations, http://www.pace.edu/current-students/commencement-2009/general-information/honorary-degree-recipients/vishakha-n-desai.</ref> Prior to becoming President, Dr. Desai held various senior positions at the Asia Society from 1990 to 2004.<ref>Abbie Fentress Swanson, "Asia Society Leader Leaves Post to Consult at Guggenheim," WNYC, 9 May 2012, http://www.wnyc.org/story/207874-asia-society-leader-leaves-post-consult-guggenheim/.</ref>
Before joining the Asia Society in 1990, Dr. Desai was at the [[Museum of Fine Arts, Boston]] as a Curator and the Head of Public Programs and Academic Affairs.<ref>"Vishakha N. Desai," South Asian Women's Leadership Forum Congress 2013: Participants, 9 March 2013, http://www.southasianwomen.org/congress/VisahakhaDesai.html.</ref> She has taught at Columbia University, [[Boston University]], and the [[University of Massachusetts]] where she was given a tenured appointment. A Scholar of Asian Art and a public intellectual, Dr. Desai is a frequent speaker at international forums on subjects focusing on cultural roots of Asia’s economic and political transformation and challenges. She has authored opinion pieces on political, cultural, and women’s development in Asia that have appeared in more than fifty publications around the world. Author of major exhibition catalogues and editor of a major scholarly publication on Asian Art History for the 21st Century, Dr. Desai is internationally recognized for her leadership in presenting contemporary Asian Art to western audiences.<ref>Sayed, R. “Dr. Vishakha Desai,” NRI Press, 20 July 2013, http://nripress.com/2013/07/20/dr-vishakha-n-desai/.</ref>
Dr. Desai is a Trustee of the [http://www.ddcf.org/ Doris Duke Charitable Foundation], and serves as Chair of the Board of Trustees for [https://afs.org/ AFS Intercultural Programs]. She is a member of the Board of Directors of [http://www.mahindra.com/ Mahindra and Mahindra], the largest multi-national corporation in India, and recently joined the Board of Directors for Teach For All, a global network of 45 independent, locally led and funded partner organizations whose stated shared mission is to expand educational opportunity around the world by increasing and accelerating the impact of social enterprises that are cultivating the leadership necessary for change. She has been an Advisory Trustee of the [[Brookings Institution]], as well as the Mayor’s Commission for Cultural Affairs in New York City, the International Advisory Committee for the [[House of World Cultures]], Berlin, and for the Auroville Foundation.<ref>, and remains involved with the [https://www.guggenheim.org/foundation Solomon Guggenheim Foundation], and [http://www.bfna.org/ Bertelsmann Foundation].
In 2012, in recognition of Dr. Desai’s leadership in the museum field, President Barack Obama appointed her to serve on the National Commission on Museums and Libraries – "Vishakha N. Desai," South Asian Women's Leadership Forum Congress 2013: Participants, 9 March 2013, http://www.southasianwomen.org/congress/VisahakhaDesai.html.</ref> She served as President of the [[Association of Art Museum Directors]] (AAMD) from 1998 to 1999 and on the board from 1995 to 2000. She has served on the board of the Andy Warhol Foundation for Visual Arts, [[College Art Association]], ArtTable, and the Massachusetts Foundation for the Humanities.<ref>"Vishakha N. Desai," South Asian Women's Leadership Forum Congress 2013: Participants, 9 March 2013, http://www.southasianwomen.org/congress/VisahakhaDesai.html.</ref>
The recipient of numerous international and national grants and fellowships, Dr. Desai has received four honorary degrees from American Universities. For her work on Asian American issues, she has received awards from the [[University of Massachusetts]], [[City University of New York]], Asian Americans for Equality, and Leadership Education for Asian Pacific Americans (LEAP).<ref>"Executive Profile: Vishakha N. Desai," Bloomberg Businessweek, http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=4995322&privcapId=4522612&previousCapId=398625&previousTitle=GOLDMAN%20SACHS%20GROUP%20INC.</ref> For her leadership in the arts, she has been honored by ArtTable, a national organization of women leaders in the arts, and has received a Gold Medal from the National Institute of Social Sciences. Dr. Desai was selected by Crain’s New York as one of the “100 most powerful women leaders” in New York, by India Abroad, the leading national weekly for Indian Americans, as one the “50 most distinguished Indian Americans,” and was honored by Zee T.V. (India) as the outstanding International Woman of the Year.<ref>"Vishakha N. Desai," South Asian Women's Leadership Forum Congress 2013: Participants, 9 March 2013, http://www.southasianwomen.org/congress/VisahakhaDesai.html.</ref>
Dr. Desai holds a B.A. in political Science from Bombay University and an M.A. and Ph.D. in Asian Art History from the University of Michigan.<ref>"Vishakha N. Desai," South Asian Women's Leadership Forum Congress 2013: Participants, 9 March 2013, http://www.southasianwomen.org/congress/VisahakhaDesai.html.</ref>
Dr. Desai is married to [[Robert Oxnam]], a China scholar, who was Asia Society’s President from 1981-1992.<ref>“Vishakha Desai,” The Asia Society, http://asiasociety.org/vishakha-desai.</ref>

Tentative List Since 11/12/2007 '''''Ref.''''': 5280 '''''Region''''': [[List of World Heritage Sites in Europe|Europe and North America]] '''''Criteria''''': ii, iii, iv, v, vi, vii '''''iucn Category''''': Mixed - natural and architectural ensemble [http://whc.unesco.org/en/statesparties/ba Bosnia and Herzegovina - UNESCO World Heritage Centre] Websites [http://www.aneks8komisija.com.ba/ Commission to Preserve National Monuments of Bosnia and Herzegovina] }} '''Vrelo Bune''' is the natural and architectural ensemble at the [[Buna (Neretva)|Buna river]] spring near [[Blagaj]] ''kasaba'' (village-town) and a part of the wider ''"Townscape ensemble of the town of Blagaj - Historical and Natural Heritage of Bosnia and Herzegovina"'' ([[Ottoman architecture|Ottoman Mediterranean architecture]], 1520), southeast of [[Mostar]], [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]]. It is impossible to separate the natural values from the cultural and historical heritage of [[Blagaj]], since its distinctive quality is in the coexistence of the natural and the man-made, in the integration of the physical structure into the [[landscape]]. == Vrelo Bune == [[File:Well of the Buna.jpg|thumb|left|A spring of Buna inside the cavern]] The [[Buna (Neretva)|Buna river]] is a short river in [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] and it is a left bank tributary of the [[Neretva]] river. Its source (''[[Bosnian language|Bosnian]]'': '''''Vrelo Bune''''') is a strong [[karst]]ic spring, emerging from a huge [[karstic]] cavern beneath a high vertical cliff. This region is specific for the diversity of its above-ground and underground [[hydrography]]. The source of the [[Buna (Neretva)|Buna river]] is the finest example of an underground [[karst]] river. It's one of the largest and most beautiful springs in Europe, producing approx. 30 m3/s with extremely cold and clean water.{{cite web|title=The natural and architectural ensemble of Blagaj |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/5280/ |publisher=[http://whc.unesco.org/ UNESCO World Heritage Centre] |accessdate=2009-05-21 Tentative List of Bosnia and Herzegovina}} == Historical and Natural Heritage == [[Blagaj]] is one of the most valuable urban-cum-rural structures in [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]]. [[Blagaj]] reached its peak of development in the 15th and 16th centuries, building in stone also reached its greatest extent. The first stone-built houses were the privilege of the wealthier class, but later, and lower-class families are also built sizeable stone houses and summer residences in large numbers.{{cite web |title=Tekke in Blagaj on the Buna Spring, the natural and architectural ensemble of Blagaj |url=http://www.aneks8komisija.com.ba/main.php?mod=galerija&action=spomenici&do=view&id_spomenika=1867&lang=4 |publisher=[http://www.aneks8komisija.com.ba/ Commission to Preserve National Monuments of Bosnia and Herzegovina] |accessdate=2009-05-22 "Tekke in Blagaj on the Buna Spring, the natural and architectural ensemble of Blagaj" }}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The natural and architectural ensemble of [[Blagaj]] forms a spatially and topographically self-contained ensemble. The region is also known for the diversity of its flora and a number of endemic species. At lower altitudes there are many evergreen plant and deciduous thicket species, while at higher altitudes in the hills there is sparse forest. Fertile cultivable land is suitable for the agriculture typical of the [[Mediterranean]] climate. === Blagaj Tekke === The architectural ensemble of the [[Blagaj]] [[Khanqah|Tekke]] (a [[Sufi]] lodge) stands by the source of the [[Buna (Neretva)|Buna river]], not far from the centre of [[Blagaj]]. The musafirhana (guest house) and [[türbe]] (mausoleum) are tucked into the natural surroundings, constituting a single entity with the cliffs, source of the [[Buna (Neretva)|Buna river]] and mills. The musafirhana of the [[Blagaj]] [[Zawiyya|tekke]] and the türbe have been preserved to this day. The musafirhana was built before 1664, and rebuilt in 1851 - its original appearance is not known. The building was subsequently repaired on several occasions. The ensemble of the Blagaj Tekke was presumably built very soon after [[History of Bosnia and Herzegovina (1463–1878)|Ottoman rule]] was established in [[Herzegovina]], around 1520 at the latest. === Bridges === There were four bridges over the 9 km of the [[Buna (Neretva)|Buna river]], two in [[Blagaj]], one in Kosor and one in [[Buna village]]. Blagaj's bridges, the Karađoz-beg bridge and Leho bridge, differ in certain features from the typological form of 16th century [[Ottoman architecture]]. * The '''Karađoz-beg bridge''' was endowed by ''Zaim hajji Mehmed-beg'', known as Karađoz, and was built before 1570, on the road to town of [[Stolac]]. The bridge has five arches, of increasing span towards the centre. * The '''Leho bridge''' or '''Lehina ćuprija''' in Donja Mahala was built before 1664 It is assumed to have been commission by ''Haseći Ali-aga Kolaković''. It had three arches, considerably wider than those of the Karađoz-beg bridige. === Mills === [[Gristmill|Mill]] buildings on the [[Buna (Neretva)|Buna river]] are simple stone-built structures with gabled roofs clad with stone slabs, and with one or more [[millstone|mill]]s. * The '''''mills by the Tekke'''''. Very close to the source of the [[Buna (Neretva)|Buna river]], channels branch off leading water to power the [[Watermill|mill]]s. Several mills, one stamping and two fulling mills were built. There was one on each bank of the river. Part of the mill on the right bank of the river has been converted into a souvenir shop. All that remains of the rest of the structure is the stone walls. * The mills in the '''''Velagić residential complex'''''. Part of the mill is on the bank and the greater part on the branch of the [[Buna (Neretva)|Buna river]] that flows beneath the ''Velagić residential complex''. The mill building consists of two parts, one built on dry land with a ground and an upper storey, and the other a single-storey structure built over the river spanning the two banks by means of a system of arches. The first part was the miller's living quarters, and the other contained seven mills arranged at regular intervals. Stamping [[Stamp mill|mill]]s were used for washing wool and fulling cloth. === Residential quarters === Residential complexes were entirely isolated in relationship with the outside world, so that the [[courtyard]] became the most important area of the house. These complexes consisted of several different buildings serving different purposes, standing on a plot that was entirely open to the natural surroundings and forming a single unit with the [[architecture]] of the buildings. * The '''''Kolaković house''''' is one of the most striking examples of residential [[architecture]] in [[Mediterranean]] [[Herzegovina]], and illustrates the evolution of the "[[History of Bosnia and Herzegovina (1463–1878)|Ottoman Bosnian]]" house. * The '''''Velagić residential complex''''' (www.velagomed.ba), built sometime before 1776, is a unique complex of the residential [[architecture]] of that time, with a large number of the functional components required for life. Although separated from the outside world, with a high wall enclosure, the interior of the complex is open to the natural environment and the [[Buna (Neretva)|Buna river]]. All the courtyards are interconnected and paved with river pebbles. The ''complex of the Velagić house'' is the most complete example of a family house complex with outbuildings, where the full scope of the residential lifestyle of [[Mediterranean]] [[Herzegovina]] in the past is revealed * The '''''Kosić tower''''', as an offshoot of mediaeval residential [[architecture]], is a typical fortified house. It is stone-built and stands at the edge of the town, so it probably served some defence purpose, given that the [[Blagaj]] fort was on the other side. == UNESCO WHS Nomination == According to the nomination for the list of national monuments in [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] with the title "''Townscape ensemble of the town of Blagaj''", drawn up by the '''''Institute for the Protection of the Cultural, Historical and Natural Heritage of Bosnia and Herzegovina''''', the source of the [[Buna (Neretva)|Buna river]] with its cliffs constitutes a geomorphological natural monument, and the source of the [[Buna (Neretva)|Buna river]] a hydrological natural monument. [[Blagaj]]'s architectural heritage and old urban quarters (''mahalas'') indicates that buildings of major monumental and townscape value occupy a relatively confined area along the [[Buna (Neretva)|Buna river]]. Urban structures, spatial physiognomy and organization can be traced from the [[mediaeval]] outskirts of the fort, which were transformed in the [[History of Bosnia and Herzegovina (1463–1878)|Ottoman period]] into a ''kasaba'' (village-town). Both [[Oriental]] and [[Mediterranean]] features are to be seen in [[Blagaj]]'s urban layout, while the settlement itself was the outcome of the influence of the natural phenomenons and configuration of the [[terrain]], as well as socio-economic relations. A perfect harmony between each buildings and its environs was achieved. == References == {{reflist}} == External links == {{Commonscat|Vrelo Bune}} *[http://www.velagomed.ba Velagomed.ba: Natural and architectural ensemble of Blagaj] *[http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/5280/ The natural and architectural ensemble of Blagaj, BiH - UNESCO WHC] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20081230034602/http://www.aneks8komisija.com.ba/index.php?lang=1 Commission to Preserve National Monuments of Bosnia and Herzegovina] *[http://whc.unesco.org/en/statesparties/ba Bosnia and Herzegovina - UNESCO World Heritage Centre] [[Category:Springs of Bosnia and Herzegovina]] [[Category:Karst springs of Bosnia and Herzegovina]] [[Category:Mostar]] [[Category:Neretva basin|SVrelo Bune]] [[Category:Sufi art]] [[Category:Ottoman architecture in Bosnia and Herzegovina]] [[Category:Protected areas of Bosnia and Herzegovina]] [[Category:World Heritage Site Tentative list]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Bosnia and Herzegovina]] [[Category:World Heritage Tentative List by Bosnia and Herzegovina]] [[Category:National Monuments of Bosnia and Herzegovina]] [[Category:Karst caves of Bosnia and Herzegovina]] [[Category:Caves of Bosnia and Herzegovina]]
